body:
It follows that convention to be consistent with rclone on other platforms. Not a great reason, I'd agree.

Note that you can find the config file on any platform with `rclone config file`
No worries just curious if anyone had ever brought it up is all

I don't think it has ever been mentioned before.

It would be possible to change it as long as we look for the config in the old place too.

Just an IT admin and I live in Windows land so this is the default place that any data should place its data normally. Does not mean it HAS to but just food for thought is all in future builds if it even maters!
Can you explain what is the difference between C:\Users{User}\AppData\Local\ or \Roaming ? What is the official way of working out where to store your config?

So in an Active Directory environment you may have what is called a roaming user that can go to any machine in the office and log in. Anything that is stored in the Roaming folder is copied back to the AD server when they log off. And any machine they log on will copy down this folder so that the next machine they log into will have this data on that machine. The Local folder is basically you installed it on this one machine and you don't want this data to travel with the user account. A lot of programmers just use the Roaming folder because it's the best of both worlds and lets say for instance we wanted to make sure rclone was installed on every machine then having the config move with the user is perfect if you forced only local then they would have to config it again on every machine they go to. Some have no idea how their app will be used so they use the roaming folder instead of the local folder. Some know exactly how they want the app to be used and it should only ever be on the machine it was installed on.

I would think in this case that the roaming folder is the best choice to place it as you don't know how rclone will be deployed it will be able to work both ways local and roaming. Just my opinion though!

@MrCaspan
1. rclone config location on Windows is explicitly documented at rclone.org
2. changing config location would break existing installations (and we don't want to make users angry)
3. in a Active Directory domain / corporate environment the user's home normally roams together with "AppData\Roaming"
4. this is just a default. if you have a strict config location policy, you are free to set user's environment `%RCLONE_CONFIG%` to point elsewhere.

cc @ncw

I think moving to `%AppData%` or `%LocalAppData%` as default on Windows is a good idea, I agree it is much more "Windows standard" - although I do have some dot-folders in my `%USERPROFILE%` (`.dotnet`, `.nuget`, etc., annoyingly enough)


> 2. changing config location would break existing installations (and we don't want to make users angry)

Not if just changing what is the default for a new configuration file when no existing is found? Rclone already looks through a list of possible locations, and first existing config file found will be used. So by adding a new location at the end of this search-list would not break anything, I think.

I don't know which of `%AppData%` (Roaming) or `%LocalAppData%` would be better...

Cache dir is already defaulting to `%LocalAppData%\rclone`, and webgui also uses this location (last time I checked).

> I think moving to `%AppData%` or `%LocalAppData%` as default on Windows is a good idea, I agree it is much more "Windows standard" - although I do have some dot-folders in my `%USERPROFILE%` (`.dotnet`, `.nuget`, etc., annoyingly enough)

I suggest the following config search order on Windows:

1. `%AppData%` (Roaming)  - to align with Windows standards
2. ~/.config/rclone/rclone.config - for compatibility
3. ~/.rclone.conf - also for compatibility

Currently rclone supports locations 2 and 3 on any OS.
Let's prepend location 1 on Windows as the primary location.
`rclone config` and `install.sh` should by default create new configs at location 1.

_the wolves are fed, the sheep are safe_ :sheep: 

> I don't know which of `%AppData%` (Roaming) or `%LocalAppData%` would be better...

`%AppData%` (Roaming) is the right place. In corporate environments (I've been a corporate employee for years) it will be restored from a central profile storage upon user login to domain and saved thereto at logoff.

> Cache dir is already defaulting to `%LocalAppData%\rclone`, and webgui also uses this location (last time I checked).

Correct. Cache should local to the machine where rclone is running.

There is the local config option also, it must have top priority:

1. \<rclone_exe_dir\>/rclone.conf
2. %AppData%/rclone/rclone.conf (default when creating new)
3. ~/.config/rclone/rclone.conf
4. ~/.rclone.conf

Currently the following is also considered, even on Windows:
`%XDG_CONFIG_HOME%\rclone\rclone.conf`

You suggest we just drop this entirely - on Windows? That will potentially be a breaking change, but would be a bit surprising if it affects anyone at all...

The documentation also seems to indicate that .rclone.conf will be picked up as well as rclone.conf, but I think this is wrong - and it will only be picked up at root of home (I think maybe I wrote this myself, so not blaming anyone... :)

> Normally the config file is in your home directory as a file called .config/rclone/rclone.conf (or .rclone.conf if created with an older version). If $XDG_CONFIG_HOME is set it will be at $XDG_CONFIG_HOME/rclone/rclone.conf.

I can have a go at this..

> You suggest we just drop this entirely - on Windows? That will potentially be a breaking change, but would be a bit surprising if it affects anyone at all...

Thank you for correction. I completely forgot about XDG stuff.

> There is the local config option also, it must have top priority:
> 1. <rclone_exe_dir>/rclone.conf

Thank you for correction (2). I didn't know about that location.

> Thank you for correction. I completely forgot about XDG stuff.

So you think %XDG_CONFIG_HOME% should still be considered on Windows, to be 100% backwards compatible?

> So you think %XDG_CONFIG_HOME% should still be considered on Windows, to be 100% backwards compatible?

Do you think we should drop or deprecate it?
Frankly, I don't really care about supporting XDG guidelines (or standard) particularly on Windows.
OTOH if it has been documented and supported for some time, and having it supported in future doesn't cost us anything,
then why not?

With your comments the proposed search path on Windows (when `--config` is omitted) becomes:

1. <rclone_exe_dir>/rclone.conf
2. %AppData%/rclone/rclone.conf (default when creating new)
3. %XDG_CONFIG_HOME%\rclone\rclone.conf
4. ~/.config/rclone/rclone.conf
5. ~/.rclone.conf

Probably location 4 can be skipped if XDG_CONFIG_HOME is set.

I

> Frankly, I don't really care about supporting XDG guidelines (or standard) particularly on Windows.

totally

> OTOH if it has been documented and supported for some time, and having it supported in future doesn't cost us anything,
then why not?

agree.

And actually there is a 6. entry according to existing code  

> Default to ./.rclone.conf (current working directory) if everything else fails.

issue.title: Change default location of config file to %AppData% on Windows

issue.body:
<!--
Thank you very much for contributing code or documentation to rclone! Please
fill out the following questions to make it easier for us to review your
changes.

You do not need to check all the boxes below all at once, feel free to take
your time and add more commits. If you're done and ready for review, please
check the last box.
-->

#### What is the purpose of this change?

Use %AppData% as primary default for configuration file on Windows, which is more in line with Windows standards, while existing default of using home directory is more Unix standards - though that made rclone more consistent accross different OS.

Main changes from existing (something for release notes?)
- Any existing configuration file should be picked up in exactly the same way as before, so no changes for **existing** configs.
  - Well.. with one possible exception: If there happens to be a file `%APPDATA%/rclone/rclone.conf`, it would not have been picked up automatically before, but could be used by explicitely referring to it with `$RCLONE_CONFIG` or `--config`, but will now be picked up automatically. That *could* lead to surprises on upgrade, but not very likely.
- Windows:
  - Default path when creating new configuration file is now `%APPDATA%/rclone/rclone.conf`.
  - Previously, configuration file would typically be created in `%USERPROFILE%\.config\rclone\rclone.conf`
    - One could set environment variable `XDG_CONFIG_HOME` and it would instead be created in `%XDG_CONFIG_HOME%/rclone/rclone.conf`, this is no longer the case (see next point).
  - `%USERPROFILE%\.config\rclone\rclone.conf` will still be used in the unlikely event of `%AppData%` not being defined, but in any case a variable `%XDG_CONFIG_HOME%` will no longer be considered when rclone is creating new config (but will still be considered if an existing configuration file is found there, to avoid breaking existing setups).


Main rules (see also changed documentation):
- If custom location configured with `$RCLONE_CONFIG` or `--config`, it will be used regardless.
- Else, search for existing file in prioritized order:
  1. `<rclone_exe_dir>/rclone.conf`
  2. `%APPDATA%/rclone/rclone.conf` (Windows only)
  3. `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/rclone/rclone.conf`
  4. `~/.config/rclone/rclone.conf`
  5. `~/.rclone.conf`
- Else, create new in default location:
  - Windows: Path 2 above.
  - Unix/non-windows: If XDG_CONFIG_HOME defined path 3, else path 4.

Note: `XDG_CONFIG_HOME` is kind of a "bastard" on Windows: This is not a common variable to set in Windows, but previous versions of rclone did consider it on all platforms, preferring it over `~/.config`. It will still be considered after this PR, for backwards compatible reasons, but only for reading existing configuration file found there.

#### Testing and documenting behavior

Tests performed with command `rclone config file`, no existing configuration file, verify what is chosen as default config location.
Last performed with beta version: https://github.com/albertony/rclone/releases/tag/v1.56.0-appdata05

Note regarding permission testing:
- Rclone will first look for a configuration file, and if not found pick a configuration directory to use for a new file.
- When picking a new configuration directory rclone will check permissions: It checks that it can create the config directory, e.g. `~/.config/rclone`, but does not verify permission to actually create a config file in it. This means when HOME is defined, but rclone has no permission to write to it, then rclone will find it cannot create directory `~/.config/rclone` and fallback to `~/.rclone.conf`, and "happily" assume that is a valid path - even though it will not actually have permission to create such a file! Attempting to create it at a later point in time (`rclone config touch`) will fail with:
  > ERROR : Failed to save config after 10 tries: Failed to create temp file for new config: open /tmp/xxx_home/.rclone.conf693553371: permission denied
- If the configuration directory already exists, e.g. `~/.config/rclone`, then permissions will not be checked. So if rclone does not (no longer) have write access here, it will still pick this one instead of using fallback - unlike what it would do if `~/.config/rclone` did not exist and rclone failed to create it.
- After the configuration file path has been found (either an existing, or path to where to store a new one), rclone will try to read it. This is also done in a simple `rclone config file` test.
  - If the file exists, a debug message is printed:
    > Using config file from %q
  - If user has permission to directory but file is not there, rclone will report notice:
    > Config file %q not found - using defaults
  - If user does not have traverse permissions to the directory, rclone will fail with fatal:
    > Failed to load config file %q: %v

Linux (arch WSL):
- Normal user (with a home)
  - XDG_CONFIG_HOME defined:
    - Permission: `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/rclone/.rclone.conf`
    - No write permission: `~/.rclone.conf`
       - Note: Does not fallback to  ~/.config/rclone/rclone.conf!
  - XDG_CONFIG_HOME **not** defined:
    - Permission to ~/.config: `~/.config/rclone/rclone.conf`
    - No write permission to ~/.config: `~/.rclone.conf`
  - No write or traverse permission to \~: `Failed to load config file "~/.rclone.conf": permission denied`
     - Note: The rclone config file command just returns this error message. It found that it could not create the config directory and that ~/.rclone.conf is the path to use, but then attempting to load it fails with "permission denied" instead of "not found".
     - Note: Does not fallback to .rclone.conf
  - HOME variable modified: `$HOME/.config/rclone/rclone.conf`
- User with no home (empty in passwd file)
  - No home-related environment: `.rclone.conf`
      ERROR : Couldn't find configuration directory nor home directory
      ERROR : Defaulting to storing config in current directory.
      ERROR : Use --config flag to workaround.
  - HOME only defined:
    - Permission: `$HOME/rclone/.rclone.conf`
    - No write permission: `$HOME/.rclone.conf`
  - HOME and XDG_CONFIG_HOME defined:
    - Permission to XDG_CONFIG_HOME: `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/rclone/.rclone.conf`
    - No write permission to XDG_CONFIG_HOME: `$HOME/.rclone.conf`
  - XDG_CONFIG_HOME only defined:
    - Permission: `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/rclone/.rclone.conf`
    - No write permission: `.rclone.conf`
      ERROR : Couldn't find home directory nor create configuration directory: mkdir $XDG_CONFIG_HOME/rclone: permission denied
      ERROR : Defaulting to storing config in current directory.
      ERROR : Use --config flag to workaround.

Windows 10:
- Normal user: `%AppData%\rclone\rclone.conf`
- No APPDATA variable, but HOME: `%HOME%\rclone\rclone.conf`
- No APPDATA, nor HOME: `%USERPROFILE%\.config\rclone\rclone.conf`
- No APPDATA, nor HOME, nor USERPROFILE: `%HOMEDRIVE%%HOMEPATH%\.config\rclone\rclone.conf`
- No APPDATA, nor HOME, nor USERPROFILE, nor HOMEDRIVE: `.rclone.conf`
  ERROR : Couldn't find configuration directory nor home directory: HOMEDRIVE, HOMEPATH, or USERPROFILE are blank
  ERROR : Defaulting to storing config in current directory.
  ERROR : Use --config flag to workaround.
- XDG_CONFIG_HOME defined, no APPDATA, HOME, USERPROFILE, nor HOMEDRIVE: `.rclone.conf`
  ERROR : Couldn't find configuration directory nor home directory: HOMEDRIVE, HOMEPATH, or USERPROFILE are blank
  ERROR : Defaulting to storing config in current directory.
  ERROR : Use --config flag to workaround.
- APPDATA set to path with no access, no HOME, USERPROFILE, nor HOMEDRIVE: `.rclone.conf`
  ERROR : Couldn't find home directory nor create configuration directory: mkdir C:\NoAccess\rclone: Access is denied.
  ERROR : Defaulting to storing config in current directory.
  ERROR : Use --config flag to workaround.
- APPDATA set to path with no access, HOME set to path with access: `%HOME%\.rclone.conf`

#### Was the change discussed in an issue or in the forum before?

Fixes #4667
